children.subject: It's on Gradescope now. We will upload it to T-sq at the end of the semester.
where will the grades be? t-square or gradescope?
I think the T-square solution, modified to add the base case T(i,0)=0 for all i would handle the case you describe. See @248

Is there a way to get more feedback on any of the problems we missed?

For problem 3, Gradescope tells me to look at the solution in T-Square. The T-Square solution, from the best I can tell, does not handle the case where the domination $$X_i$$ must replace the dominations used in $$X_{i-1}$$ to minimize T(x, b). For example if X = {2, 3, 5}, k = 1, and B=5, the T-Square solution (I may be mistaken) will return false because the recurrence is defined to take either the answer $$T[i-1, n]$$, which is 2, or $$T[i-1, b-X_i]$$, which is infinity.

Mine solution is similar, to the T-Square solution but shoving the above case in there made it kind of weird. I'm not sure my solution its completely right since it kind of loses track of which coins have been used.

I submitted homework 1 on gradescope, and verified that it showed it was submitted (went through and assigned each page to the appropriate problem). But when I go into gradescope now, it says "No submission". Is anyone else having this issue?

I can't see a score or anything like that

EDIT: Woops, I seem to have two separate gradescope accounts attached to this class... hope that doesn't present an issue
Given the definition and recurrence, it's good enough if we can understand your code in 30-60 sec.

On pseudo code, I think you'll get a much more consistent submission if you provide some guidelines for the granularity of pseudo code you're looking for. Pseudo code is not at all standardized and all code is a form of "pseudo code" (we aren't listing out the instructions to the processor, are we?). The important question is what level of abstraction are we expected to use in writing our algorithms?

For example, should I just write english sentences for each step, or use mathematical set notation to indicate iterating over a set of numbers? I did the latter on my homework, but it takes a long time to format that way in latex

Also, don't forget to identify which pages in your submission are for which problem.  After uploading a pdf, Gradescope will ask you to match pages to problems.  I overlooked this step with homework 1.  Apologies, TAs.

history.content:
Here is the feedback on the homework 1, please check list and make some modification on your further homework/exam if necessary.

Some general feedback:

  1. Match your homework/exam problem with the outlines we provided otherwise we cannot grade your work.
  2. Make sure your pseudo code is clean and concise, which means, a real code is not a pseudo code. We need to read your pseudo code if we cannot understand your definition or recurrence, and we won't be able to spend a long time on your code. So make it abstract and clean, and make sure it matches what you defined before, otherwise it doesn't help and we will deduct points for that.
  3. Make sure your logic is consistent. If you defined something at first, make it clear and understandable. And the answers following it (such as recurrence, pseudo code or analysis) need to be consistent to your definition.
  4. Late homework won't be accepted. But don't be worry, it's only 5% total. It's more like a practice for you to understand the materials and prepare for the exams.
  5. Make sure you only provide exactly one answer instead of multiple choices for us. If there are multiple answers, we will pick the worst one to assign grade.

Feedback on HW1:

  1. Solve your DP problems in a DP WAY, that is, you will need your results of the subproblems you calculated before to solve the current problem. If you use non-DP algorithm to solve the problem, we won't give you points even if you are correct.
  2. Define your table entry IN A CLEAR WAY: if you use any index like i or j, please explain what they means and how they related to your table entries. It there is some norm you invented, you will also need to explain it.
  3. Check your recurrence, and we suggest you prove the correctness before you write it down by trying your best to find counterexamples to your recurrence. Some recurrence doesn't make any sense, and the part c and d cannot be correct in this case. But don't worry, once you've done enough practice and reflection (very important), you will make it!
  4. Make sure your definition, recurrence, pseudo code and analysis are consistent.
  5. Please consider the BASE CASE. DP algorithm won't work without define your base case correctly. You will need that in your recurrence and your pseudo code.

Thanks and good luck!

#pin
